Although few say that the current military effort in Iraq and Syria is going well, a majority of people still believe that the U.S. and its allies will ultimately succeed in their campaign against ISIS. This is an increase from July 2015, when 55% thought they would succeed. The public is divided over the question of sending U.S. ground troops to fight Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria, with 47% in favor and 47% opposed. Views are little different than in July, when 49% were opposed and 44% were in favor of sending U.S. ground troops to Iraq and Syria. The recent attacks in Paris, France and San Bernardino, Calif. have not led to a fundamental shift in how the public views the U.S. military campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria. Overall, a 64%-majority continues to say they approve of the U.S. military campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria, while just 28% say they disapprove. Support for the U.S. military effort has been steady over the course of 2015.

The survey found that 1,051 interviews were conducted via cellphone, while 449 interviews were conducted via landline. The total number of interviews conducted was 1,500. The report also notes that the sample was corrected for a potential bias associated with re-contacting previously interviewed respondents in low-incidence strata. The sample was also corrected for within-household selection in landline interviews, which depended upon the number of Latino adults living in the household. The sample was corrected for the oversampling of telephone number exchanges known to have higher densities of Latinos and the corresponding under sampling of exchanges known to have lower densities of Latinos. Finally, the data were put through a post-stratification sample balancing routine. The post-stratification weighting utilized estimates of the U.S. adult Hispanic population based on the 2013 U.S. Census Bureau’s American Community Survey, on gender, age, education, Census region, heritage and years in the U.S. Phone status of the U.S. adult Hispanic population (i.e., cellphone only, dual/landline only) is based on estimates from the January-June 2015 National Health Interview Survey conducted by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; the density of the Latino population is from the 2010 Census. The weights are then trimmed to avoid any particular case having too much influence on the results. The report also notes that the sample was compared with InfoUSA and Experian landline household databases, and phone numbers associated with households that included persons with known Latino surnames were subdivided into a surname stratum. The remaining, unmatched and unlisted landline sample was used to generate a stratum with a high incidence of Latinos, based upon the share of Latinos in the sample telephone exchange. The sample was divided into high and medium strata, based upon the share of Latinos in the sample telephone area code. The study employed a dual-frame landline/cellular telephone design to ensure the highest possible coverage of the eligible population. The study employed six strata. The sample consisted of a landline sampling frame (yielding 449 completed interviews) and a cellphone sampling frame (1,051 interviews). Both the landline and cellphone sampling frames used a stratified sampling design, oversampling areas with higher densities of Latino residents. The political orientations of Republican and Democratic voters have shifted significantly from 2008 to 2016. In 2008, 59% of Republican voters wanted their party to work with Obama, while in 2016, only 36% of Republican voters wanted their party to work with Clinton. In contrast, in 2008, 38% of Democratic voters wanted their party to move to the left, while in 2016, 49% of Democratic voters wanted their party to move to the left. This shift indicates a growing divide between the two parties and a more polarized political landscape.

In 2016, 26% of Trump voters said he should appoint Democrats to his administration, while in 2008, 52% of Obama voters said he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet. This shows that Obama voters were more open to appointing members from the opposition party than Trump voters were in 2016.

From July to December 2015, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS showed a slight increase in support, with 47% of Americans favoring the use of U.S. ground forces against ISIS, up from 44% in July. The public's overall concerns about the rise of Islamic extremism at home and abroad remained high but did not increase from September 2014. The percentage of people who viewed ISIS as a major threat to the U.S. rose by 16 points since August 2014, with 93% of Republicans, 79% of Democrats, and 93% of independents considering it a major threat. The balance of opinion shifted since early 2014, with more people saying that relying too much on force creates hatred (57%) compared to 37% who said overwhelming military force was the best way to defeat terrorism. The percentage of people who said the U.S. and its allies will succeed in their campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria increased by 11 points from July to December 2015, with 66% saying they will definitely or probably succeed.

Perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have shown little change over time, with the share of the public saying this remaining at 46% in 2015, down from a historical high of 50% in 2014. However, these opinions have become more politically polarized, with 68% of Republicans saying Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a historical high, while only 30% of Democrats agree, down from 42% in 2014. The partisan divide over this issue is now as wide as it has ever been. The age gap in these views has also narrowed, with 51% of Americans 65 and older saying Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence, down from 64% in 2014. The ideological divide is even starker, with 77% of conservative Republicans saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions, compared to just 16% who say it does not. Liberal Democrats' opinion is nearly the inverse, with 73% saying Islam is no more likely to encourage violence than other religions. The share of liberals saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence is down 14 points since the fall of 2014.

Americans generally express more worry than enthusiasm about the concept of machines performing jobs currently done by humans. Most Americans are familiar with the idea and consider it realistic, with 72% expressing worry and 33% expressing enthusiasm. The perception varies by political affiliation, with Democrats and Republicans having different levels of concern and support for interventions like a universal basic income. There is also a significant difference in views between those who have heard a lot about the concept and those who have not. The majority of Americans anticipate significant changes to the nature of jobs and work due to automation, with 77% finding the idea realistic. However, there is a notable difference in views between those who have been impacted by automation in their careers and the general population. Overall, the concept is seen as plausible, with more negative than positive outcomes anticipated.

The public is divided on whether businesses should be limited in the number of human jobs they can replace with machines, with 58% supporting limits and 41% opposing them. However, there is strong support for limiting machines to performing dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with 85% in favor. Additionally, 60% support a guaranteed income for displaced workers, and 58% support a national service program to pay humans for jobs even if machines can do them faster or cheaper. There are no major partisan differences in support for limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs, but Democrats are more supportive of a universal basic income and a national service program for displaced workers. The public is also concerned about the impact of widespread automation, with 77% considering it plausible and expressing more worry than enthusiasm.

Perceptions of job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats. Republicans are more likely to view job availability positively, with 71% saying there are plenty of jobs available locally, compared to 53% of Democrats. This partisan gap has widened since 2017, with Republicans' views becoming more positive and Democrats' views becoming more negative. The majority of Republicans (71%) and Democrats (53%) now say there are plenty of jobs available locally, but Republicans' views are more positive than Democrats'.

This indicates a growing trend of both parties wanting their leaders to take a more confrontational stance against the opposition.

Confidence is expressed qualitatively and ranges from low confidence (inconclusive evidence or disagreement among experts) to very high confidence (strong evidence and high consensus). Likelihood, or the probability of an impact, is a term that allows a quantitative estimate of uncertainty to be associated with projections, ranging from very unlikely (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance of the outcome occurring) to very likely (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance). The evaluation process involves assessing the available literature, determining the quality and quantity of available evidence, and evaluating the level of agreement across different studies. The appropriate level of confidence or likelihood is determined by the chapter author teams based on their expert assessment and consensus. The process is documented in the Traceable Accounts section for each chapter, and more information is available in Appendix 1: Technical Support Document and Appendix 4: Documenting Uncertainty. The document also includes a table that defines the likelihood levels, ranging from very unlikely to very likely, with specific probability ranges associated with each level. The confidence levels are also defined, ranging from low to very high, based on the strength of the evidence and expert agreement. The document emphasizes the importance of using both qualitative and quantitative measures to assess the uncertainty associated with specific statements. The evaluation process is designed to provide a comprehensive, evidence-based, and quantitative estimation of observed and projected climate change related health impacts in the United States. The document draws from a large body of scientific peer-reviewed research and other publicly available sources, all of which meet the standards of the Information Quality Act (IQA). The report was extensively reviewed by the public and experts, including a committee of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, the 13 Federal agencies of the U.S. Global Change Research Program, and the Federal Committee on Environment, Natural Resources, and Sustainability (CENRS). The document also includes research highlights, which are quantitative analyses of projected impacts conducted for inclusion in the report. Each analysis is summarized with a brief description of the study's importance, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions. The analyses are all published in external peer-reviewed sources, and the full description of modeling methods and findings can be found in those citations. Perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism vary significantly among different educational and political affiliation groups. For instance, among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" does not describe the GOP or the Democratic Party, while 43% say it describes one and not the other, and 17% think it describes both. Additionally, partisans are somewhat less positive about their own party in views on whether it has high ethical standards, though majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their party this way. Among Republicans and Republican leaners, these views diverge significantly by ideology. Overall, opinions about the traits of the two parties continue to be deeply divided along partisan lines.

Perceptions of ethical standards and extremism differ between the Republican and Democratic parties, with the Republican Party being viewed as more extreme and the Democratic Party as having higher ethical standards. These perceptions are influenced by education, with those with at least a college degree being more likely to view both parties as having high ethical standards. Political affiliation also plays a role, with partisans being less positive about their own party's ethical standards. Independents are more likely to view neither party as having high ethical standards. The Republican Party is viewed as having good policy ideas by 50% of the public, while the Democratic Party is viewed similarly. However, more Americans view the Republican Party as too extreme than the Democratic Party. The public's views on the two parties' ethical standards and extremism are deeply divided along partisan lines, with majorities of both Republicans and Democrats saying their own party has good policy ideas and high ethical standards.

Perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences vary significantly among different education levels and political affiliations. For instance, a higher percentage of college graduates view neither party as having high ethical standards compared to those with a high school degree or less education. Additionally, there are differences in early midterm vote preferences, with those with a postgraduate degree favoring the Democratic candidate over the Republican by a two-to-one margin, while those with a four-year college degree favor the Democrat by a 53% to 40% margin. Preferences are more divided among voters who do not have a college degree. Furthermore, partisans are somewhat less positive about their own party in views on whether it has high ethical standards, with majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describing their party this way. However, a quarter of the public says "high ethical standards" describes neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party, 47% say it describes one party but not the other, and 17% say the description applies to both. Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" does not describe the GOP or the Democratic Party; 43% say it describes one and not the other, and 17% think it describes both. Finally, there are sizable educational differences in early midterm vote preferences, with those with a postgraduate degree favoring the Democratic candidate over the Republican by roughly two-to-one (62% to 30%) and those with a four-year college degree favoring the Democrat, 53% to 40%. Preferences are more divided among voters who do not have a college degree.

Views on Trump's handling of economic policy are mixed, with 53% expressing at least some confidence and 46% having little or no confidence. In contrast, perceptions of his ethical standards are more divided, with 15% of conservative Republicans expressing negative views, 36% of moderate and liberal Republicans rating them as not good or poor, and 86% of Democrats rating them negatively. This suggests that while some may have confidence in his economic decisions, there is a significant portion of the public, particularly Democrats, who do not trust his ethical judgment.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has increased since January, with 53% expressing at least some confidence in his economic policy decisions and 43% in his handling of international crises. However, these figures are still lower than those of previous presidents. Republicans have grown significantly more confident in Trump's ability to handle international crises, with 84% now expressing confidence compared to 73% in January. Democrats continue to overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct as president, with 85% disliking his behavior. Partisan perspectives show a stark divide, with Republicans showing increased confidence in Trump's economic and international crisis handling abilities, while Democrats remain largely critical.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has increased since January, with 53% expressing at least some confidence in his economic policy decisions and 43% in his ability to handle international crises. This is higher than earlier this year, when 46% had little or no confidence in his economic policy and 35% in his ability to handle international crises. Overall, Republicans and Republican leaners are more likely to say they like Trump's conduct, with 80% agreeing with him on many or all issues, compared to 69% in August. Democrats, on the other hand, overwhelmingly say they do not like the way Trump conducts himself, with only 10% saying they have mixed feelings and 5% saying they like his behavior. These views have remained little changed since August.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis has increased from 35% in January 2018 to 43% in May 2018, while confidence in his ability to make good decisions about economic policy has also risen from 46% in January 2018 to 53% in May 2018. These improvements in public perception are evident in the line graphs provided.

The opinions among Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration have remained relatively stable over time. While there are some differences in views by race, age, and education, the overall ratings for Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration have not significantly changed since August. The public's evaluation of the way Donald Trump is handling his job as president is little changed in recent months and is roughly on par with ratings at the outset of his presidency. The ratings for the Trump administration's ethical standards are lower than for those at various points in other administrations dating back to when the question was first asked by ABC News and The Washington Post of Ronald Reagan's administration in 1983.

The approval ratings of Trump's administration officials' ethical standards are significantly lower compared to those of past administrations, with only 11% rating them as excellent or good, and 58% rating them as not good or poor. This is reflected in the public's overall disapproval of Trump's job performance, with 42% disapproving strongly and 12% disapproving not so strongly. The ratings for Trump officials' ethical standards trail past administrations, indicating a negative perception of the administration's conduct.

Educational levels and political affiliations significantly impact perceptions of ethical standards and approval ratings of Trump. Higher education levels are associated with more negative views of Trump's ethical standards, with 26% of those with some college experience and 20% of those with a high school degree or less rating his ethical standards as not good or poor. Conversely, 36% of moderate and liberal Republicans and 15% of conservative Republicans express negative views of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials. Independents are more likely than partisans to say neither party has high ethical standards, with 34% of independents, including equal shares of Republican leaners and Democratic leaners, saying neither party has high ethical standards. By comparison, only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%) say this. The public's evaluation of the way Donald Trump is handling his job as president is little changed in recent months and is roughly on par with ratings at the outset of his presidency. The public has similar views of the Republican and Democratic parties in assessments of their policy ideas and ethical standards. However, somewhat more Americans view the Republican Party than the Democratic Party as "too extreme." Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" does not describe the GOP or the Democratic Party; 43% say it describes one and not the other, and 17% think it describes both.

Voter reactions to the 2016 U.S. presidential election were notably more negative compared to previous elections, with a significant portion expressing disappointment and surprise at Trump's victory. The most prevalent emotions among voters were unease, sadness, and fear, with 53%, 41%, and 41% of voters respectively feeling these emotions. In contrast, 51% of voters felt hopeful, and 36% felt proud. The reactions were less positive than those following Obama's election in 2008, where 69% of voters felt hopeful and 35% felt uneasy. The survey also found that 97% of Trump voters were happy with his win, while 93% of Clinton voters were unhappy, indicating a stark divide in emotional responses.

The emotional reactions to Trump's election differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters. Trump voters predominantly feel hopeful and proud, with 96% and 74% respectively, while Clinton voters predominantly feel uneasy, sad, and scared, with 90%, 77%, and 76% respectively. Clinton voters with college degrees express more anger and sadness than those with less education. In contrast, Trump voters are optimistic about his first term, with 97% expecting it to be successful, compared to only 15% of Clinton supporters. The perceptions of Republicans and Democrats differ significantly in terms of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and its impact on U.S.-China relations. Republicans are more critical of China's response, with 82% saying China has done a bad job, compared to 54% of Democrats. Republicans are also more likely to believe China's initial handling contributed greatly to the global spread of the virus, at 73%, compared to 38% of Democrats. In terms of U.S.-China relations, Republicans are more likely to prioritize holding China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it means worsening economic relations, with 71% in favor, compared to 37% of Democrats. Republicans are also much more likely to say they have a very unfavorable view of China (54%) than Democrats (35%). This trend has been consistent for much of the last 15 years.

The perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 vary significantly among different age groups and political affiliations. Older Americans and Republicans are more critical of China's response, with 73% of those aged 50 and older and 82% of Republicans believing China's initial handling contributed a great deal to the global spread of the virus. In contrast, only 38% of Democrats share this view. The survey also shows that 64% of Americans overall think China has done a bad job handling the pandemic, with 43% believing it has done a very bad job. The data indicates a clear divide in opinions, with Republicans and older individuals being more critical than Democrats and younger individuals.

Political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany significantly influence preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. In the U.S., Republicans and Democrats have different priorities, with Republicans favoring Israel and Democrats emphasizing Canada and Mexico. Both groups, however, rank Germany similarly as a top foreign policy partner. In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU and SPD/Greens prioritize France and the U.S. respectively. Americans generally want more cooperation with European allies, while Germans are less inclined to cooperate with the U.S. However, there is a growing trend among Germans to cooperate more with the U.S. since 2018. Both Americans and Germans support increased cooperation with France and Japan, but Americans prefer the UK more than Germans. There is also a convergence in support for cooperation with China. Regarding Russia, Germans are more likely to want greater collaboration, with East Germans showing higher support than West Germans. In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined towards Russia than Democrats. The data also shows that younger Americans and Germans are more likely to consider Germany and the U.S. important for foreign policy, while older individuals are more likely to view these relationships as not important. Overall, political affiliations play a crucial role in shaping foreign policy preferences and cooperation levels between the U.S. and Germany.

The differences in preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China between Americans and Germans are significant. Americans are more likely to prefer cooperation with China, with 58% of Americans ages 18 to 29 saying it is more important for their country to have a close relationship with China than Germany (32%). In contrast, Germans are about twice as likely to say they prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%). This preference is more pronounced among younger Americans, while older Americans prefer Germany over China. In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD. In the U.S., there are slight partisan differences in the choice of a close relationship with Russia or Germany, with about two-thirds of Democrats (66%) saying they prefer close ties with Germany, compared with 57% of Republicans. Republicans are more likely to prefer close relations with Russia (31%) than Democrats (21%). These differences in preferences are influenced by political party affiliations, with conservative Americans and Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum being more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals and those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU. The divide is notably wider between Americans than it is between Germans.

American and German perceptions on the necessity of military force and defense spending differ significantly. The political affiliations and educational backgrounds of Americans significantly influence their perceptions of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Republicans and those with higher educational attainment are more critical of the U.S.'s response, while Democrats and those with lower educational attainment are more critical of China's response. The perception of the U.S.'s handling is more divided along party lines, with Republicans generally praising the response and Democrats criticizing it. Conversely, the perception of China's handling is less divided, with majorities across all educational groups and political affiliations saying China has not handled the pandemic well. The data also shows that older Americans tend to have less favorable attitudes towards China's response compared to younger Americans. The differences in perceptions are less pronounced when evaluating other countries' responses, such as Italy, South Korea, and Germany.

The perception of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic is significantly influenced by political affiliations. Republicans are more likely to view the U.S. response positively, with 71% rating it as good or excellent, compared to 27% of Democrats. The perception of other countries, such as Germany and South Korea, is less affected by political affiliations, with differences of less than 10 percentage points between Democrats and Republicans. The perception of the U.S.'s international influence after the pandemic is split, with roughly equal shares believing it will be bolstered, weakened, or remain the same.

Similarly, 72% of Americans with a college degree trust information from the EU about the coronavirus outbreak, and 70% of those with a postgraduate degree trust information from the WHO. These differences in trust and perceptions highlight the impact of political affiliation and education level on attitudes towards international cooperation and information sharing during the pandemic.

For instance, 53% of Americans have confidence in Biden to deal with China, while 91% consider cyberattacks from China to be very or somewhat serious. Similarly, 53% see the U.S. trade deficit with China as a very serious problem, and 84% view China's growing military power as a very serious issue. These figures indicate a significant gap between public confidence in Biden's handling of China and the perceived severity of related issues.

The level of confidence in Biden to deal effectively with China varies significantly across different demographic groups. Women, Black, and Hispanic adults express more confidence than White adults, with 59%, 82%, and 70% respectively, compared to 43% for White adults. Those with a college degree have a higher confidence rate at 60% compared to 50% for those with less schooling. The primary concerns Americans have regarding China include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights. These issues are seen as very serious problems by a substantial portion of the population, with 91% considering cyberattacks from China very serious, 86% for China's growing military power, 85% for the U.S. trade deficit with China, and 84% for the loss of U.S. jobs to China.

Confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies significantly among different demographic and political groups. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%). Those with a college degree have higher confidence (60%) than those with less schooling (50%). Partisan differences are substantial, with 83% of Democrats and 19% of Republicans having confidence in Biden on China. Concerns about China's human rights policies increased between 2018 and 2020. The most serious concerns about China include cyber attacks, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights.

Major concerns Americans have regarding China include cyber attacks, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights. Partisan differences are also notable, with 83% of Democrats and 19% of Republicans expressing confidence in Biden on China.

American perceptions of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly negative, with 54% saying China has done a bad job and 28% believing it has done a very bad job. In contrast, 90% of Americans believe China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people. Regarding priorities in U.S.-China relations, 70% of Americans prioritize promoting human rights, even if it harms economic relations, while only 8% prioritize economic relations, even if it means not addressing human rights issues. This indicates a strong preference for human rights over economic considerations in the U.S.-China relationship.

The balance between promoting human rights and economic relations with China is perceived differently across various political affiliations in the U.S. According to the data, 70% of Americans prioritize human rights over economic ties with China, even if it potentially harms economic relations. Among Republicans, conservative Republicans are more likely to hold this opinion, with 81% prioritizing human rights. In contrast, among Democrats, liberal Democrats are the most likely to emphasize human rights over economic dealings in U.S.-China relations. The data also shows that 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents want the U.S. to get tougher with China on trade, while 60% of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer building stronger ties with China. The perception that China's human rights policies are a major problem and support for promoting human rights in China are issues that Democrats and Republicans largely agree on. However, the U.S.'s weakening role as a superpower in global competition against China is a concern for 64% of Americans. The trade war and bans on sales to certain companies have hurt businesses, and 44% of Americans believe the U.S. has not managed its relationship with China well under the Trump administration.

The majority of Americans, regardless of their political affiliation, prioritize promoting human rights over economic relations with China. This is evident from the data showing that 70% of Americans choose human rights over economic ties with China. This suggests that while there is a general consensus on prioritizing human rights, there are notable differences in views on trade policies between different political groups.

The perspectives of different political affiliations on the impacts of tariffs and international students in the U.S. show significant differences. Republicans are more likely to view tariffs positively, with 51% considering them good for the U.S., compared to 11% of Democrats. On the other hand, Democrats are more likely to see international students as an asset, with 92% of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents holding this view, while only 67% of Republicans and Republican leaners agree. These differences highlight the polarized views within the U.S. on economic policies and immigration.

Opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly across age and political affiliation. Older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and older, are more likely to support limiting Chinese students, with 58% considering it a top priority, compared to 39% of those under 50. This trend is mirrored in political affiliation, with Republicans more likely to support limitations on Chinese students than Democrats. Among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents, only 33% support limiting Chinese students, while 63% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents do. Confidence in Chinese leadership, particularly President Xi, is also a factor, with older Americans expressing less confidence in him than younger Americans. While 53% of those aged 65 and older have no confidence at all in Xi, only 35% of those aged 18 to 29 share this sentiment. This lack of confidence in Chinese leadership may contribute to the differing opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities.

American perceptions of China have become significantly more negative from 2018 to 2021, with a substantial increase in the share of people feeling "very cold" towards China. The major concerns driving these perceptions include human rights issues, particularly the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang, which has been labeled a "genocide" by former U.S. officials. Economic concerns, such as China's dominance as a manufacturing center and the U.S.-Chinese economic relationship, also play a significant role. Additionally, there is a growing sense of threat from China's growing technological power, cyber attacks, and the loss of U.S. jobs to China. The partisan gap in these perceptions has also grown, with Republicans showing a much higher level of concern compared to Democrats.

The key concerns of Americans regarding China include cyber attacks, job losses to China, China's growing technological power, and China's policies on human rights. These concerns have increased over time, with 58% of Americans now considering cyber attacks from China a very serious problem, up from 43% in 2020. Additionally, 53% of Americans believe China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people, and 55% think China is doing a bad job dealing with the coronavirus pandemic. The U.S. trade deficit with China and tensions between mainland China and Taiwan are also significant concerns. The survey also shows that 64% of Americans describe economic relations between the superpowers as somewhat or very bad.

From 2008 to 2015, financial optimism among different Hispanic subgroups increased significantly, with the largest gains seen among those with some college education (+20 percentage points) and those with a high school diploma or less education (+11 percentage points). In contrast, the general population's optimism increased by only 6 percentage points. By 2015, 81% of Latinos expected their family's financial situation to improve, compared to 61% of the general public. This trend has been consistent since 2004, with Latinos consistently more optimistic about their finances than the general public. The gap in financial expectations between Latinos and the general public has grown, reaching 20 percentage points in 2015, the largest since the series began.

Hispanics with a positive view of their current financial situation are significantly more likely than those who rate their economic circumstances as only fair or poor to say their family's finances will improve over the next 12 months. Most Hispanics are confident their finances will improve in the next year and also see a bright financial future for their children. Those already prospering are the most likely to be optimistic in their expectations about the next year. Latino adults also see upward mobility in their children's futures. Fully 72% say they expect their children will be better off financially than they themselves are now. Views also differ by age, with older Latinos more pessimistic about their children's financial futures than younger Latinos. Among those ages 65 and older, 52% say their children will be better off than themselves. By comparison, 75% of Latinos ages 18 to 29 have similar expectations of their children, as do 76% of those ages 30 to 49 and 70% of those ages 50 to 64. Among those ages 65 and older, 13% say their children will be less well off, higher than among Latinos ages 18 to 29 and 30 to 49. There are differences by educational attainment among Latinos. Among those with at least some college experience, 69% expect their children will be better off financially, with a similar share (71%) of those with less than a high school education saying the same. However, Latino high school graduates are more optimistic than those with some college experience or more, with 79% predicting that their children will be better off financially.

From 2000 to 2015, the perceptions of financial well-being among Latinos have generally improved, with a significant increase in optimism about their family's financial future. The unemployment rate for Latinos has also declined, although it remains higher than that of non-Hispanic workers. The Hispanic community has shown a growing economic footprint, with a rise in purchasing power and a significant impact on the nation's economy. However, community economic indicators show limited progress since the Great Recession, with stagnant median household income and a higher poverty rate compared to pre-recession levels. The optimism among Latinos about their children's financial future has also increased, with a majority expecting their children to be better off financially than they themselves are. The Hispanic community has outpaced the general U.S. population in their views of their personal finances and optimism about the future.

The data shows that the unemployment rate for Hispanics has been higher than that of non-Hispanics, particularly during the Great Recession, as indicated by the graph in image8. This trend has persisted, with Hispanics having a higher unemployment rate in 2015 compared to non-Hispanics. Despite this, Hispanics have shown a more positive outlook on their economic situation and future prospects, as seen in image1 and image7, where a larger percentage of Hispanics expect their children to be better off financially than themselves. This optimism contrasts with the more pessimistic views of non-Hispanics. The income disparity is evident in image2, where the median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining lower than that of non-Hispanics. Additionally, the wealth disparity is highlighted in image3, where Hispanic households experienced a larger percentage decline in net worth through 2009 compared to non-Hispanic households. The data suggests that while Hispanics face economic challenges, they maintain a hopeful outlook on their future economic prospects, which may influence their attitudes towards economic policies and support for initiatives aimed at improving their economic situation.

From 2000 to 2015, Hispanic households faced higher unemployment rates compared to all U.S. households, with a peak during the Great Recession. Median household income for Hispanics stagnated, remaining at $42,491, while the general U.S. public's income also saw little change. The Hispanic poverty rate was 23.6% in 2014, slightly lower than the peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels. Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession. Overall, Hispanic households faced more significant economic challenges in terms of unemployment, income, poverty rate, and wealth compared to all U.S. households during this period.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors vary significantly compared to all adults. Seniors are less likely to go online initially but tend to make the internet a regular part of their daily routine once they start. Among seniors who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week. This frequency is higher than the general population, with 86% of all adults using the internet daily or almost daily. Device ownership among seniors is notably lower, with only 18% owning smartphones and 47% having broadband at home, compared to 91% of all adults owning cell phones and 70% having broadband. The trend shows that seniors, especially those aged 75 and above, have lower internet and broadband adoption rates, with usage and adoption rates dropping dramatically around this age. However, younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors use the internet and broadband at rates approaching or exceeding the general population. Social network adopters among seniors have more persistent social connections with the people they care about, with 81% of older adults who use social networking sites saying they socialize with others daily or near-daily. The data also indicates that seniors with higher education and income levels are more likely to adopt the internet and broadband.

The device ownership among older adults is lower than their internet usage patterns. While 59% of seniors report using the internet, only 18% own smartphones, and 27% use social networking sites. This suggests that many older adults are using the internet through devices other than smartphones, such as tablets or e-book readers, and are not necessarily using social media. The data also shows that older adults who use the internet are more likely to go online daily or almost daily, indicating a regular pattern of internet use. However, the overall levels of internet and device ownership among seniors are still lower than the general population.

Device ownership and online activity differ significantly between seniors and the general adult population. Among the general public, smartphones are much more common than tablets or e-book readers, with 55% ownership compared to 18% for both tablets and e-book readers. However, among older adults, the ownership of tablets and e-book readers is identical to that of smartphones at 18%. The proportion of seniors who own either a tablet or an e-book reader is actually larger than the proportion owning a smartphone, with 27% owning a tablet, an e-book reader, or both, while 18% own a smartphone. Despite these low overall levels of usage as a group, certain portions of the senior population have internet and broadband adoption rates that are equal to—or in some cases greater than—rates among the general public. For example, 46% of online seniors use social networking sites such as Facebook, and these social network adopters have more persistent social connections with the people they care about. The trend in internet adoption over time shows that seniors have a lower rate of internet usage compared to the general population, with 59% of seniors using the internet compared to 86% of all U.S. adults. However, usage rates among seniors have been increasing, with a six percentage point year-over-year increase from 53% in 2012 to 59% in 2013. The adoption of smartphones among older adults has also been growing at a relatively modest pace, with 18% of seniors being smartphone adopters, well below the national adoption rate of 55%. The adoption levels among seniors who have not attended college and those with an annual household income of less than $30,000 per year are similar, with slightly more than one third of those 80 years of age or older using the internet and just one in five members of this age group having a broadband connection at home.

Seniors' device ownership trends, such as tablets and e-book readers, are more prevalent than their online social networking usage habits. While 27% of seniors use social networking sites, 27% own a tablet or e-book reader, and 18% own a smartphone. This suggests that seniors are more likely to own devices than actively engage in social networking.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income. Younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors use the internet and broadband at rates approaching or exceeding the general population, with adoption rates dropping dramatically around age 75. For example, 68% of seniors aged 65-69 use the internet, compared to 21% of those aged 80 and older. Seniors with higher education levels and higher incomes also have higher adoption rates. However, overall, seniors still trail the general population, with 59% of seniors using the internet compared to 86% of all U.S. adults. The adoption of smartphones among seniors is also lower, with only 18% owning smartphones, compared to 55% of the general population. The data shows that while there are pockets of seniors with high adoption rates, the overall trend is that seniors are less likely to use the internet and broadband compared to the general adult population.

Internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors vary significantly by income and education levels. Seniors with higher incomes and college degrees have higher adoption rates for all three technologies compared to those with lower incomes and less education. For example, 90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, while only 39% of those earning less than $30,000 do the same. Similarly, 87% of college graduates go online, compared to 40% of those with some college education. Cell phone ownership is also more common among higher-income and more educated seniors, with 77% of all seniors owning a cell phone, but this rate is higher among those with higher incomes and more education. Smartphone adoption is the lowest among all groups, with only 18% of seniors owning a smartphone, and this rate is even lower among those with lower incomes and less education. Overall, the data suggests that seniors with higher incomes and more education are more likely to adopt these technologies, while those with lower incomes and less education are more likely to be left behind.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults (65+) vary significantly by income and education. Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower levels of income and educational attainment. For example, seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more are around four times as likely to own an e-book reader and a tablet as those with a household income of less than $30,000 per year. Similarly, seniors who have graduated from college are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet as those who have not attended college. However, smartphone ownership remains low among seniors, with just 18% of seniors being smartphone adopters, which is well below the national adoption rate of 55%. Despite these low overall levels of usage as a group, certain portions of the senior population have internet and broadband adoption rates that are equal to—or in some cases greater than—rates among the general public. For instance, seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more are more than double the rate among seniors as a whole, but roughly half the smartphone ownership rate among high-income adults within the general population. Overall, the adoption of internet and broadband has more than doubled over a five-year period, with 59% of seniors reporting they go online and 47% saying they have a high-speed broadband connection at home.

Internet usage and smartphone ownership vary significantly among seniors with different educational backgrounds. Seniors with a high school education or less have the lowest internet usage and smartphone ownership rates, with only 40% using the internet and 10% owning a smartphone. In contrast, college graduates have the highest rates, with 87% using the internet and 35% owning a smartphone. The trend shows that higher educational attainment is associated with higher technology adoption among seniors.![Internet usage and smartphone ownership vary among seniors with different educational backgrounds.](image1)![Higher educational attainment is associated with higher technology adoption among seniors.](image2)

Internet and broadband adoption among seniors is significantly higher among those with higher education and income levels, with 87% of college graduates and 90% of those earning $75,000 or more per year going online, and 76% and 82% having broadband at home, respectively. In contrast, smartphone ownership is low across all age groups, with only 18% of seniors owning smartphones, and this rate is even lower among those 80 years or older and those with lower incomes. Cell phone ownership is more widespread, with 77% of seniors owning a cell phone, and this rate is higher among those with higher incomes and education levels. The adoption of e-book readers and tablets is also more common among college graduates and higher-income seniors. Overall, the data suggests that while cell phone ownership is widespread among seniors, smartphone adoption is still relatively low, and internet and broadband usage is more prevalent among those with higher education and income levels.

Broadband adoption at home among seniors varies significantly based on their educational attainment and household income. Seniors with a college degree are more likely to have broadband at home, with 76% adoption compared to 27% for those without a college degree. Additionally, seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more are more likely to have broadband at home, with 82% adoption compared to 25% for those with a household income of less than $30,000. This indicates that higher education and income levels are associated with higher broadband adoption rates among seniors.

Education level significantly affects the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors. Seniors with a college degree are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to those without a college degree. This trend is consistent with the overall population, where tablets and e-book readers are most popular among college graduates and higher-income Americans. The adoption of technology among different age groups has shown a steady increase over time, with younger cohorts adopting technology at a faster rate than older ones. For example, 54% of internet users aged 65-69 use social networking sites, compared to just 27% of internet users aged 80 and older. This trend is reflected in the increasing adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, with 22% of seniors with a life-impacting disability or chronic disease owning either a tablet computer or an e-book reader. The adoption of smartphones among seniors has been growing at a relatively modest pace, with just 18% of seniors being smartphone adopters, well below the national adoption rate of 55%. Overall, education level plays a crucial role in the adoption of technology among seniors, and the trend of increasing adoption over time is evident across different age groups.

Workers with higher levels of education, particularly those with college degrees, have more positive views of workplace technologies and their impact on job interest and career opportunities. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with high school diplomas or less. The differences in perceptions are most pronounced for office productivity tools like word processing and spreadsheet software, with a 45-percentage point difference between college graduates (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%). Additionally, college graduates are more likely to say that technology has made their work less demanding, while those with high school diplomas or less are more likely to report that technology has made their work more demanding. The survey also found that nearly one-quarter of workers with high school diplomas or less say that none of the six technologies surveyed have had a positive impact on their jobs or careers, compared to just 2% of college graduates. Overall, the data suggests that education level plays a significant role in shaping perceptions of workplace technologies and their impact on job interest and career opportunities.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of workplace technologies, particularly regarding making work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement. For example, 64% of college graduates find their work more interesting due to technology, compared to 38% of those with high school diplomas or less. Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities for advancement, while only 32% of those with high school diplomas or less feel the same. These differences are most pronounced in the case of office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software, with a 45-percentage point difference between the two groups. In total, nearly one-quarter of workers with high school diplomas or less say that none of the six technologies have had a positive impact on their jobs or careers, while for college graduates that figure is just 2%. However, those who have not attended college are much less likely to view today’s workforce technologies in such a positive light.

Americans' levels of awareness about automation significantly affect their enthusiasm and worry about machines taking over human jobs. Those most familiar with the concept express more enthusiasm but also substantial concerns. Roughly three-quarters of Americans who have heard a lot about this concept express some level of worry about a future in which machines do many jobs currently done by humans. This worry is comparable to those who have heard a little about the concept and those who have not heard anything about it before. However, those with high levels of awareness are more enthusiastic about the idea of robots and computers someday doing many human jobs, a figure that is also substantially higher than among those with lower levels of familiarity with this concept. In terms of expected outcomes, Americans generally expect more negative than positive results from widespread automation. Roughly three-quarters of Americans expect that widespread automation will lead to much greater levels of economic inequality than exist today, while nearly two-thirds expect that people will have a hard time finding things to do with their lives. Only 25% of Americans expect that the economy will create many new, well-paying jobs for humans in the event that workforce automation capabilities become much more advanced than they are today. Larger shares expect that this development would make the economy more efficient, let people focus on the most fulfilling aspects of their jobs, or allow them to focus less on work and more on what really matters to them.

Public opinion on workforce automation policies varies significantly between Democrats and Republicans. Democrats are more supportive of policies such as a universal basic income and a national service program for displaced workers, with 77% and 66% support respectively, compared to 38% and 46% among Republicans. However, there are no major partisan differences in support for limiting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs, with 85% of Americans favoring this policy. Additionally, 60% of Democrats and 54% of Republicans believe there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines. The public is also strongly supportive of limiting robots and computers to dangerous jobs, with 85% in favor. The most prominent differences in Americans' views relate to political affiliation, with Democrats showing higher support for income and service programs.

Political affiliations and education levels significantly influence opinions on government obligations and automation limits related to job displacement. Democrats and those with higher education levels are more supportive of government obligations to care for displaced workers and limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate. In contrast, Republicans and those with lower education levels are more likely to believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being and are less supportive of government intervention. The data shows that 65% of Democrats and 68% of Republicans feel that the government should take care of displaced workers, while 70% of those with high school diplomas or less support limits on job automation compared to 41% of those with four-year college degrees. Additionally, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, compared to 38% of Republicans, and 66% of Democrats support a national service program, compared to 46% of Republicans. These differences highlight the varying perspectives on government roles and automation impacts based on political and educational backgrounds.

Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of policies related to workforce automation and job displacement, such as a universal basic income and a national service program, compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning independents. Democrats are more likely to believe the government should take care of displaced workers, while Republicans believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being. There are no major partisan differences in support for limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs or giving people the option to pay extra to interact with a human rather than a robot in commercial transactions. However, there are significant differences in support for these policies among different educational levels, with those who have attended but not graduated from college being more supportive than those with four-year college degrees. The public is evenly divided on whether government or individuals should be responsible for providing for displaced workers, but is more supportive of limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines. The vast majority of Americans, regardless of party affiliation, support limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs.

Attitudes towards workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly among different age groups and education levels. Younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 24, are more likely to have been personally impacted by automation, with 6% reporting job loss or wage reduction due to automation. College graduates are more likely to view technology positively, with 64% finding their work more interesting and 53% believing it has increased their career advancement opportunities. In contrast, workers with high school diplomas or less are less likely to express positive attitudes towards technology, with only 38% finding their work more interesting and 32% believing it has increased their career advancement opportunities. The impact of technology on jobs and careers is also influenced by industry, with workers in hospitality and service, or retail, being more likely to view their jobs as at risk compared to those in education. Overall, the benefits of technology are most likely to accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment, while those who have not attended college are much less likely to view today's workforce technologies in a positive light.

The perceptions of the impact of workforce automation and technology vary significantly across different demographics and education levels. Workers with higher levels of education, such as those with college degrees, are more likely to view technology positively, finding it makes their work more interesting and increases their opportunities for career advancement. In contrast, workers with lower levels of education, such as those with high school diplomas or less, are less likely to view technology positively, with many seeing it as a negative influence on their career prospects. The survey also found that the benefits of technology are most likely to accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment. Additionally, the impact of technology on jobs and careers is felt differently by various demographic groups, with young adults and certain other groups reporting being impacted at higher levels than average. The survey asked about the impact of six common workforce technologies, including word processing and spreadsheet software, smartphones, email and social media, software that manages daily schedules, technologies that help customers serve themselves, and industrial robots. Workers with college degrees are substantially more likely than those who have not attended college to say that each of these individual technologies has had a positive impact on their jobs or careers. The survey also found that workers express mixed views about the impact of various workforce technologies, with some viewing them in a positive light, while others see them as damaging or neutral to their career prospects. Overall, the survey highlights the disparate impacts of technology on today's workforce, with benefits most likely to accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment.

Workers' perceptions of their job's interest and advancement opportunities are significantly influenced by their education levels and the specific technologies they use. College graduates are more likely to find their jobs interesting and have increased opportunities for advancement compared to those with high school diplomas or less. Specific technologies, such as word processing and spreadsheet software, smartphones, and email or social media, are generally viewed positively by workers, with higher percentages of positive views among those with higher education levels. However, industrial robots are perceived more negatively, especially by those with less education. The impact of technology on job interest and advancement opportunities varies across different job types, with some professions like fast food workers and insurance claims processors showing higher positive impacts. The duration of technology use also affects perceptions, with longer-term users generally having more positive views. Overall, education and technology type play crucial roles in shaping workers' attitudes towards their jobs.

Perceptions of fairness and effectiveness vary significantly across different automated systems used for decision-making. For instance, the personal finance score algorithm is viewed as effective by 54% of Americans but only 32% find it fair, indicating a notable gap in public trust. In contrast, the automated criminal risk score is seen as fair by 50% and effective by 49%, suggesting a more balanced perception. These differences imply that while some systems are trusted for their effectiveness, they may not be equally trusted for fairness, potentially leading to public skepticism and concerns about the potential for bias and discrimination. The context in which these systems are used also plays a role, with some technologies being viewed more favorably in certain scenarios. Overall, the public's skepticism spans several dimensions, including concerns about fairness, the removal of the human element, and the inability of these systems to capture the nuance of complex situations. This skepticism is context-dependent, with otherwise similar technologies being viewed with support or suspicion depending on the circumstances or tasks they are assigned to do. Demographic differences are relatively modest on the question of fairness, although there is some notable variation related to race and ethnicity. For example, Blacks and Hispanics are more likely than whites to find the consumer finance score concept fair to consumers. However, Blacks express much more concern about a parole scoring algorithm than do either whites or Hispanics. The public is relatively split on whether these programs would be effective at doing the job they are designed to do, with some 54% thinking the personal finance score program would be effective at identifying good customers, while around half think the parole rating (49%) and resume screening (47%) algorithms would be effective. Meanwhile, 39% think the video job interview concept would be a good way to identify successful hires. The context dependence is especially notable in the public’s contrasting attitudes toward the criminal risk score and personal finance score concepts. Similar shares of the population think these programs would be effective at doing the job they are supposed to do, with 54% thinking the personal finance score algorithm would do a good job at identifying people who would be good customers and 49% thinking the criminal risk score would be effective at identifying people who are deserving of parole. But a larger share of Americans think the criminal risk score would be fair to those it is analyzing. Half (50%) think this type of algorithm would be fair to people who are up for parole, but just 32% think the personal finance score concept would be fair to consumers

Public perceptions of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness are significantly lower compared to those of previous presidents. A majority of the public (58%) trusts what Trump says less than they trusted what previous presidents said while in office, with only 26% saying they trust Trump more and 14% saying their level of trust is about the same. This distrust has increased since April 2017, when a smaller share (51%) said they trusted what Trump says less than previous presidents. Among Republicans and Republican leaners, 58% say they trust what Trump says more than previous presidents, while 25% say they trust what he says about the same as previous presidents, and 15% say they trust his rhetoric less. In contrast, almost all Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) say they trust what Trump says less than they trusted what previous presidents said while in office. Partisan views of Trump's economic policies have become more polarized since the fall of 2017, with nearly eight-in-ten Republicans and Republican leaners (79%) saying that his economic policies have improved conditions in the country, up from 63% in October 2017. Democrats and Democratic leaners, by contrast, have grown more negative in their views of Trump's economic policies, with almost half (46%) now saying his policies have made conditions worse. The overall trend indicates a growing divide in public opinion along party lines, with Republicans becoming more critical of Wall Street and Democrats expressing more negative views.

The public's confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is significantly lower than his confidence in negotiating trade agreements or managing the executive branch. Republicans are more confident in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts than Democrats, with 51% of Republicans expressing confidence compared to 19% of Democrats. This confidence level is lower than the 89% of Republicans who are confident in Trump's ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements and the 51% who are confident in his ability to manage the executive branch. Democrats, on the other hand, are much less confident in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts, with only 11% expressing confidence. This is in contrast to the 49% of Democrats who are confident in Trump's ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements and the 35% who are confident in his ability to manage the executive branch. Overall, the public's confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is lower than his confidence in other tasks, with Republicans expressing more confidence than Democrats.

This skepticism is particularly pronounced among liberal Democrats, with 83% expressing no confidence. In contrast, Republicans are less likely to believe Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, with only 32% saying he does, while 64% say he does not. American perceptions of state government COVID-19 response differ significantly from their views on Trump's handling of the pandemic. While 51% of Americans rate state and local governments' response as effective, only 30% believe the federal government's response has been effective. In contrast, 48% of Americans rate Trump's response as "poor," indicating a higher level of criticism towards his handling of the pandemic compared to state and local governments. This suggests that while there is some dissatisfaction with state and local responses, the federal response is viewed more negatively by the public.

Americans' perceptions of the effectiveness in handling COVID-19 show a significant decline in positive evaluations of both elected officials and public health officials since March. Public health officials, such as those with the CDC, have seen a decrease in positive ratings from 79% to 63%. Elected officials, including state and local government officials, have also experienced a decline, with state officials' ratings dropping from 69% to 60% and local officials' ratings from 70% to 56%. The public continues to express overwhelmingly positive views of the response of local hospital and medical centers, with 88% rating them as excellent or good, which has remained unchanged. The majority of Americans, 62%, believe the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak has been less effective compared to other wealthy countries, while only 13% say it has been more effective. The new national survey by Pew Research Center, conducted July 27-Aug. 2 among 11,001 adults on the Center’s American Trends Panel, finds broadly negative assessments of the overall U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak – and increasingly critical evaluations of how Donald Trump, state and local government officials, and public health officials have dealt with the crisis. The shift in views has come almost entirely among Republicans; only about half of Republicans (53%) give CDC officials and other public health officials positive ratings for their response to the outbreak, 31 points lower than in late March (84%). About seven-in-ten Democrats (72%) say public health officials have done an excellent or good job in responding to the coronavirus, little changed since March (74%). Public divided over which level of government is primarily responsible for policies to limit the spread of COVID-19. Republicans and Democrats have divergent opinions about nearly all aspects of the coronavirus outbreak, and this includes views of the U.S. response compared with other affluent nations. While more Republicans than Democrats offer positive assessments of the U.S. response, just 22% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents say the U.S. has been more effective than other wealthy countries; a larger share (34%) say it has been less effective, while 42% say it has been about as effective. Democrats and Democratic leaners overwhelmingly view the U.S. response to the coronavirus as less effective compared with other wealthy countries (87% say this).
